results_summary: The study found no significant differences in primary outcomes (death/ICU admission or discharge/NEWS2 ≤ 2) between lactoferrin and placebo groups. Lactoferrin demonstrated excellent safety and tolerability but did not show clinical benefit for COVID-19 patients.
population_specificity: Hospitalized adult patients with moderate-to-severe COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bovine lactoferrin (bLF) could prevent SARS-CoV-2 infection in healthcare personnel.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in SARS-CoV-2 infection rates between the bLF and placebo groups, nor any effect on time to symptomatic infection or secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthcare personnel in two tertiary hospitals in Lima, Peru.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if HBV infection alters breast milk composition, specifically lactoferrin levels, and whether newborns of HBV-positive mothers require additional lactoferrin supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that HBV infection decreased lactoferrin concentrations in breast milk (average 537.68 pg/mL), suggesting that additional lactoferrin supplementation may be necessary for newborns of HBV-positive mothers.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with HBV infection and their newborns, compared to a healthy control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of donor milk processing techniques, including pasteurization, on the digestion and absorption of lactoferrin and other milk components in preterm infants.
results_summary: Heating during pasteurization increased proteolysis of lactoferrin and caseins but did not affect protein hydrolysis in vitro; the abundance and diversity of released peptides remain unclear. Fat homogenization improved fat digestion, while high-pressure processing showed minimal impact compared to Holder pasteurization.
population_specificity: Preterm infants receiving donor human milk.

study_goal: To determine the impact of supplemental bovine lactoferrin on the gut microbiome and metabolome of preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found minimal impacts of lactoferrin on gut microbiome diversity and composition, with hospital site and postnatal age explaining more variation. No significant differences in microbiome Shannon diversity were observed between lactoferrin and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born <32 weeks' gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of human milk (containing lactoferrin) and formula milk on infant gut microbiome and health.
results_summary: The study highlights that lactoferrin, as a bioactive component in human milk, contributes to immunological development and promotes a healthy gut microbiome in infants. Formula milk supplemented with prebiotics or probiotics attempts to mimic these effects but results in differing gut microbiomes compared to breastfed infants.
population_specificity: Infants (specifically comparing breastfed and formula-fed infants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of a food supplement containing lactoferrin, combined with a topical cream, in treating adult female acne.
results_summary: The combination treatment (C + O) showed significantly greater reduction in inflammatory lesions and acne severity scores compared to the topical treatment alone, with a 73% reduction in inflammatory lesions and a 55% improvement in AFAST score at Week 12. Both treatments were well tolerated with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Adult women aged 25–40 with adult female acne (AFA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (combined with prebiotics, zinc, and niacinamide in a food supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lactoferrin supplementation could prevent preterm birth in women at high risk.
results_summary: Lactoferrin supplementation was associated with a lower risk of preterm birth before 37 weeks (OR=0.43) and higher gestational age at delivery (MD=0.46 weeks). However, its role in preventing preterm birth via inflammatory modulation remains unclear.
population_specificity: Pregnant women at high risk for preterm birth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the evidence for the effect of Lactoferrin supplementation on inflammation, immune function, and respiratory tract infections in humans.
results_summary: Lactoferrin supplementation reduced systemic inflammation in adults (notably IL-6) and improved immune function in some studies. It also reduced respiratory tract infection incidence in infants and children but not in adults.
population_specificity: Human subjects of all ages (20 studies in adults, 5 in children).
effective_dosage: 200 mg Lf/day for inflammation; 35-833 mg Lf/day in formulas for RTIs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of prophylactic enteral bovine lactoferrin in preventing severe neonatal diseases (e.g., LOS, NEC) in premature infants.
results_summary: Lactoferrin did not reduce the incidence of LOS, NEC, or overall mortality but significantly accelerated the achievement of full enteral feeds and reduced hospital stay duration in the smallest infants.
population_specificity: Premature infants with gestational age ≤32 weeks, birth weight ≤1,500 g, and age ≤72 hours.
study_duration: Until postmenstrual age of 36 weeks or discharge (at least 4 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the effects of orally administered lactoferrin in preventing and managing viral infections across different virus families.
results_summary: The study found heterogeneous results with no clear conclusion on lactoferrin's antiviral effects, though some weak positive outcomes were noted in symptom severity, duration, and viral load reduction. Most trials had high risk of bias, and findings varied widely across viral families.
population_specificity: People of any age with confirmed viral infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of lactoferrin as an immunomodulatory and antimicrobial supplement for preventing and treating COVID-19.
results_summary: The study suggests lactoferrin has potential utility in COVID-19 due to its immunomodulatory and antimicrobial properties, though clinical data specific to COVID-19 is limited.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Lactoferrin, Metformin, and TUDCA on high glucose-induced cellular stress in INS1 β-cells and MSCs.
results_summary: Lactoferrin, along with Metformin and TUDCA, effectively mitigated high glucose-induced cellular stress, restored proliferation and migration in MSCs, and normalized glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in INS1 β-cells. The effects were observed at the gene and protein expression levels.
population_specificity: INS1 β-cells and mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Lactoferrin's potential as an antiviral and immune regulator for COVID-19 prevention and adjunct treatment.
results_summary: The study highlights Lactoferrin's in vitro antiviral efficacy against SARS-CoV-2 and its immunomodulatory effects, suggesting potential benefits for COVID-19, but clinical validation is pending.
population_specificity: Not specified (general potential application for COVID-19).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical benefits and safety of enteral lactoferrin supplementation in preterm neonates based on evidence from randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Lactoferrin supplementation showed clinical benefits in reducing late-onset sepsis, late-onset fungal sepsis, hospital length of stay, and urinary tract infections, with no reported adverse effects. However, it did not significantly decrease necrotizing enterocolitis, mortality, or neurodevelopmental impairment.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the preventative effects of bovine lactoferrin (bLF) on late-onset sepsis (LOS) in infants with a birth weight <1500 g and its relation to human milk intake.
results_summary: The study evaluated bLF's effectiveness in preventing culture-proven or probable LOS in very low birth weight infants, combining data from two randomized controlled trials with similar designs and dosages.
population_specificity: Infants with a birth weight <1500 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of lactoferrin supplementation, in combination with other nutrients, on gut microbiota development and markers of gut barrier maturation in healthy term infants.
results_summary: Infants fed formula containing BMOS (which included lactoferrin) showed lower calprotectin levels and microbiota profiles closer to breastfed infants, suggesting improved gut maturation. No significant differences were observed for neopterin.
population_specificity: Healthy term infants in their early life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether bovine lactoferrin (bLf) supplementation disrupts intestinal microbiota development in preterm infants receiving prophylactic probiotics.
results_summary: The study found that bLf supplementation had minimal impact on microbiota composition or function, with no significant differences in taxa relative abundance or functional gene content between groups. Infants receiving bLf showed higher species richness, but the overall effect on microbiota development was negligible.
population_specificity: Preterm infants less than 31 weeks gestational age.
effective_dosage: 100 mg bLf daily, mixed with feeds (human milk or formula).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing the enteral diet of very low-birthweight infants with lactoferrin reduces all-cause mortality or major morbidity.
results_summary: Lactoferrin supplementation did not significantly improve death or major morbidity but might reduce late-onset sepsis, as indicated by a meta-analysis of over 5000 infants. Three serious adverse reactions occurred, but none were definitively attributed to lactoferrin.
population_specificity: Very low-birthweight or preterm infants (weighing less than 1500 g and aged less than 8 days).
study_duration: Until 34 weeks' post-menstrual age (or for 2 weeks, if longer), or until discharge from the study hospital if earlier.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of undenatured whey protein isolate (WPI) with standardized lactoferrin content on oxidative stress and inflammation in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The WPI group showed significant reductions in markers of oxidative stress and inflammation, improved lipid profile, and reduced fasting plasma glucose compared to placebo. No changes were observed in body weight, BMI, or other metabolic markers in either group.
population_specificity: 120 white patients with type 2 diabetes and glycated hemoglobin ≥6.5%.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only lactoferrin content ≥0.7% in WPI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bovine lactoferrin supplementation could prevent late-onset sepsis (LOS) and neurodevelopmental delay in low birth weight neonates.
results_summary: Bovine lactoferrin did not significantly reduce the incidence of LOS or sepsis-associated death compared to placebo, though there was a non-significant trend favoring lactoferrin. Neurodevelopment and growth outcomes at 24 months were similar between groups, but bronchiolitis rates were significantly lower in the lactoferrin group.
population_specificity: Neonates with birth weights of 500-2000 g in Lima, Peru.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the role of lactoferrin supplementation in preventing late-onset sepsis (LOS) in preterm infants.
results_summary: Lactoferrin supplementation, with or without probiotics, reduced the incidence of all LOS (RR: 0.56; 95% CI: 0.36-0.86). The evidence was of low to moderate quality, suggesting a beneficial effect, but further research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Preterm infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether bovine lactoferrin (BLF) supplementation reduces late-onset sepsis (LOS) in preterm infants, particularly comparing its effectiveness in those fed mother's own milk (MM) versus formula/donor milk (no-MM).
results_summary: BLF supplementation significantly reduced LOS incidence in preterm infants, with a relative risk reduction of 0.66 (95% CI: 0.18-0.64) in MM-fed infants. The study suggests BLF may be more effective in infants not exclusively fed MM, warranting further investigation.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether supplementation with lactoferrin is effective in preventing necrotising enterocolitis (NEC) or infection in very preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with lactoferrin, among other immunonutrients, was not effective in preventing NEC or infection in very preterm infants based on randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Very preterm infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bovine lactoferrin (bLF), combined with GOS and vitamin D, could restore TLR responsiveness in pDCs and mDCs and reduce inflammatory markers in elderly women.
results_summary: The study found that the nutritional intervention (bLF, GOS, and vitamin D) improved TLR-mediated responses in dendritic cells and reduced inflammatory markers in serum, suggesting potential benefits for immune function in aging.
population_specificity: Elderly women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding bovine lactoferrin (bLF) to feeds in very-low birthweight (VLBW) infants improves survival free from major morbidities and other clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study is designed to evaluate the impact of bLF on survival free from brain injury, sepsis, NEC, and retinopathy, as well as secondary outcomes like time to full enteral feeds and hospital stay, but results are not yet available (pre-results).
population_specificity: Very-low birthweight (VLBW) infants (<1500 g) in Australia and New Zealand.
effective_dosage: Up to 250 mg/kg/day bLF added to breast milk or formula.
study_duration: Until 34 completed weeks corrected gestation or for 2 weeks (whichever is longer), or until discharge if earlier.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of vitamin D₃ supplementation on salivary immune functions and symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) in vitamin D-insufficient taekwondo athletes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Lactoferrin.
population_specificity: 25 male taekwondo athletes, aged 19⁻22 years, with vitamin D insufficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize lactoferrin's role in protecting newborns from infection and supporting immune system maturation, as well as review clinical trials on its use for preventing sepsis and necrotizing enterocolitis.
results_summary: Lactoferrin exhibits antimicrobial and immunomodulatory functions, playing a critical role in neonatal infection protection and immune system development. Clinical trials suggest potential benefits in preventing sepsis and necrotizing enterocolitis, warranting further study.
population_specificity: Newborn infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of lactoferrin supplementation as a treatment for taste and smell abnormalities (TSA) in chemotherapy patients and investigate related mechanisms through salivary proteome analysis.
results_summary: Lactoferrin supplementation significantly reduced salivary Fe concentration, increased immune protein expression, and decreased TSA scores in chemotherapy patients, while also improving oral immunity.
population_specificity: 19 cancer patients with TSA post-chemotherapy and 12 healthy subjects.
effective_dosage: 3 tablets per day (250 mg per tablet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if prophylactic enteral bovine lactoferrin supplementation reduces late-onset invasive infection and other complications in very preterm infants.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported yet; it will assess infection incidence, mortality, and other outcomes, with potential follow-up on neurodevelopmental impacts at 5 years.
population_specificity: Very preterm infants (born at < 32 weeks' gestation) in UK neonatal care centres.
study_duration: From shortly after birth until 34 weeks' post-menstrual age

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lactoferrin supplementation could prevent late-onset sepsis (LOS) and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in preterm infants while assessing its safety.
results_summary: Lactoferrin significantly reduced the incidence of LOS, NEC, hospital-acquired infections, and infection-related mortality, while also shortening the time to full enteral feeding. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Preterm infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bovine lactoferrin (BLF) supplementation could counteract the increased risk of late-onset sepsis (LOS) in preterm infants exposed to inhibitors of gastric acidity.
results_summary: The study found that BLF supplementation reduced the additional risk of LOS associated with inhibitors of gastric acidity exposure, lowering the risk increase from 7.7% per day in untreated infants to 1.2% per day in treated infants. BLF was particularly effective against Gram-negative and fungal pathogens.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight (VLBW) preterm infants in the neonatal intensive care unit.
interactions: Inhibitors of gastric acidity (H2 blockers or proton pump inhibitors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if daily supplementation with lactoferrin and lysozyme could reduce environmental enteric dysfunction (EED) and stunting in rural Malawian children aged 12-23 months.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes a planned study rather than reporting outcomes.
population_specificity: Rural Malawian children aged 12-23 months at high risk for EED and stunting.
study_duration: 16 weeks (primary outcomes measured at 8 and 16 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether probiotics, including Lactoferrin, had any significant effects on immune responses in sedentary young males following resistance exercise.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in salivary Lactoferrin levels between groups or between pre- and post-test measurements, indicating no detectable effect of probiotics or circuit training on Lactoferrin responses.
population_specificity: Forty-one healthy sedentary young males.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Lactoferrin (probiotics were administered twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers examined whether vitamin D3 supplementation affects salivary lactoferrin secretion rates in athletes during winter training.
results_summary: The study did not report significant changes in lactoferrin secretion rates in either the vitamin D3 or placebo groups.
population_specificity: 39 healthy male athletes

study_goal: To determine the tolerability of bovine lactoferrin (bLF) in very preterm infants and assess whether the intervention could be adequately masked.
results_summary: The study found no effect of bLF on feeding tolerance, mortality, late-onset sepsis, or other complications of prematurity. Parents in both groups equally believed their infants received bLF, indicating successful masking.
population_specificity: Very preterm infants under 31 weeks gestation.
study_duration: Intervention began before 48 hours of age; duration to achieve full feeds (140 ml/kg per day) was measured.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of short-term supplementation with bovine whey-derived lactoferrin and immunoglobulins in free-living adults.
results_summary: Supplementation was well tolerated with no significant adverse effects, and routine clinical measures remained largely unchanged. Body composition and metabolic indices showed minor fluctuations but no significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Free-living adults (n=20 per group).
effective_dosage: 200 mg lactoferrin, 200 mg or 800 mg immunoglobulins, or combinations (200 mg/200 mg, 200 mg/800 mg).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of bovine lactoferrin (BLF) in preventing the first episode of late-onset sepsis (LOS) in low birth weight (LBW) neonates.
results_summary: BLF supplementation significantly reduced the incidence of first-episode culture-proven LOS (3.2% vs. 13.4%) and sepsis-attributable mortality (0% vs. 7.5%) compared to placebo. The results were statistically significant (p = 0.036 and p = 0.027, respectively).
population_specificity: Low birth weight (<2000 g) neonates admitted to the NICU within the first 12 hours of birth, with no maternal risk factors for sepsis.
effective_dosage: Increasing doses of BLF were used with higher birth weights (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: 28 days (from the 1st to the 28th day of life).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the glycosylation pattern of goat milk lactoferrin and compare it with human and bovine milk glycoproteins.
results_summary: The study identified 65 glycan structures in goat milk lactoferrin, with 37% sialylated and 34% fucosylated. It found similarities between human and goat milk glycans but also novel glycans unique to goat milk, suggesting potential bioactive benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on milk glycoprotein analysis, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bovine lactoferrin (BLF), alone or combined with LGG, could reduce the incidence of NEC in very-low-birth-weight neonates.
results_summary: BLF alone or with LGG significantly reduced NEC incidence (2.0% and 0%, respectively) compared to controls (5.4%). The combination also lowered death-and/or-NEC incidence (4.0% and 3.8% vs. 10.1% in controls).
population_specificity: Very-low-birth-weight neonates (<1500 g at birth) in tertiary neonatal intensive care units.
effective_dosage: BLF (100 mg/day) alone or with LGG (6×10^9 CFU/day).
study_duration: From birth until day 30 of life (45 days for neonates <1000 g at birth).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lactoferrin supplementation, combined with lysozyme, could improve gut health (measured by EED biomarkers) and linear growth in children during their second year of life.
results_summary: The study found a modest but significant short-term improvement in gut health (Δ%L) at 8 weeks, though the effect weakened by 16 weeks. The intervention significantly reduced hospitalization and acute malnutrition rates but did not affect linear growth.
population_specificity: Rural Malawian children aged 12-23 months.
effective_dosage: 1.5 g lactoferrin and 0.2 g lysozyme daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of camel milk, including its component lactoferrin, in managing type 1 diabetes by examining its effects on blood glucose levels, insulin dose, and beta cell function.
results_summary: The study suggests that camel milk, containing lactoferrin and other bioactive components, may help maintain hyperglycemia and improve diabetic management, supported by epidemiological surveys showing lower diabetes prevalence in communities consuming camel milk.
population_specificity: Type 1 diabetic patients

study_goal: To determine the effect of bovine lactoferrin (bLF) on preventing diarrhea in children.
results_summary: The study found no difference in diarrhea incidence between bLF and placebo groups, but bLF reduced diarrhea longitudinal prevalence, episode duration, severity of dehydration, and liquid stool load. No adverse events related to bLF were reported.
population_specificity: Previously weaned children aged 12-18 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a bovine lactoferrin/whey protein Ig-rich fraction (Lf/IgF) combination could reduce the number of colds and improve symptom recovery in individuals prone to frequent upper respiratory infections.
results_summary: The Lf/IgF combination significantly reduced the incidence of colds (48 vs. 112 in placebo) and the cumulative number of cold-related symptoms compared to placebo, though reductions in total days sick and cold severity were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 126 males and females with self-reported frequent upper respiratory tract symptoms and infections, matched by age, BMI, dietary, and physical parameters.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exclusive feeding with fresh maternal milk (which includes lactoferrin) could prevent retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in very low birth weight (VLBW) infants compared to formula feeding.
results_summary: The study found that infants fed exclusively with maternal milk had significantly lower incidences of ROP (any stage) and threshold ROP compared to formula-fed infants, with multivariate analysis confirming the protective effect of maternal milk.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight (VLBW) neonates in a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) setting.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on maternal milk vs. formula, not isolated lactoferrin dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (duration of feeding intervention not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if bovine lactoferrin (bLF) supplementation could protect children aged 2-6 years against EV71 or rotavirus infection and influence serum levels of IFN-γ and IL-10.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefits of bLF in preventing EV71 or rotavirus infections or altering IFN-γ and IL-10 levels. No differences in infection incidence or cytokine levels were observed between the bLF and control groups.
population_specificity: Healthy children aged 2-6 years in a day care center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Lactosucrose (LS) on TNBS-induced colitis in rats, focusing on its potential to modulate immunity and reduce inflammation.
results_summary: LS supplementation ameliorated TNBS-induced colitis by increasing IL-10 production, suppressing IL-12 secretion, and reducing TLR-2 and NF-κB p65 protein levels, indicating anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Rats with TNBS-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of lactosucrose on intestinal microflora and its protective role against indomethacin-induced enteropathy in rats.
results_summary: Lactosucrose reduced the severity of small-intestinal ulcers compared to sucrose, with fewer increases in Enterobacteriaceae and streptococci, suggesting a protective effect linked to maintaining intestinal microflora.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: Not specified (lactosucrose was fed as part of the diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of lactosucrose (LS) on intestinal calcium absorption in healthy young women with lower-than-recommended calcium intakes.
results_summary: LS administration significantly reduced fecal pH, ammonia, and putrefactive products while increasing short-chain fatty acids (SCFA). It also improved calcium absorption and retention, as well as magnesium and phosphorus absorption, compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy young women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate lactoferrin's role in bone growth, its mechanisms of action in osteoblasts and osteoclasts, and its potential as a therapeutic agent for osteoporosis.
results_summary: Lactoferrin promotes bone growth by stimulating osteoblast proliferation and differentiation while inhibiting osteoclastogenesis, leading to increased bone volume. It activates signaling pathways (p42/44 MAPK, PI3-kinase/Akt) and genes (IGF1, Ptgs2, Nfatc1) in osteoblasts, and dietary supplementation improves bone mineral density and strength.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies mentioned, but no human population details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of fibre intake and supplementation, including lactosucrose, during haematological cancer treatment to assess its impact on clinical outcomes and the gastrointestinal microbiome.
results_summary: The study identified lactosucrose as part of a combination fibre supplement used during stem cell transplantation, but specific efficacy or safety results for lactosucrose alone were not detailed. Outcomes focused on tolerability, clinical results (e.g., infection, graft versus host disease), and microbiome impact.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing chemotherapy, immunotherapy, or stem cell transplantation for haematological malignancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a short-term, laughter-based intervention on mental health and cognitive functions in middle-aged adults.
results_summary: The study found that viewing a short comedic video significantly improved digit vigilance scores and increased cerebral blood flow in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, suggesting enhanced focus. It also indicated potential activation of parasympathetic activity and reduced psychological stress levels.
population_specificity: 25 healthy Japanese-speaking adults aged 40 to 65.
effective_dosage: Approximately four minutes of comedic video exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and describe gelastic (laugh-related) spells in individuals with Angelman syndrome (AS) and differentiate them from other paroxysmal events like seizures and cataplexy.
results_summary: The study reported three cases of gelastic syncope in individuals with AS and one case of transient breath-holding while laughing, adding gelastic syncope to the list of paroxysmal events in AS. The findings may help inform providers and parents about this phenotype and guide evaluation and treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals with Angelman syndrome (one child and two adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of laughter therapy on psychological (stress, anxiety, depression) and physical (pain, fatigue, sleep quality) symptoms in cancer patients.
results_summary: Laughter therapy effectively improved stress, anxiety, depression, pain, and fatigue in cancer patients but had no effect on sleep quality. It was described as safe, interactive, and feasible, potentially enhancing patient communication and trust in healthcare.
population_specificity: Cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of laughter yoga on nursing students' perceptions of stress and meaning of life before clinical practice.
results_summary: Laughter yoga significantly improved nursing students' perceived stress levels and sense of meaning and purpose in life, with statistically significant differences observed between pre- and post-test scores.
population_specificity: First-year nursing students (91.1% women, 97.8% single, mean age ~19 years).
effective_dosage: Eight sessions over four weeks (twice weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on the efficacy of laughter therapy in relieving psychological symptoms (stress, depression, anxiety) in cancer patients.
results_summary: Meta-analysis showed laughter therapy combined with routine nursing significantly reduced stress, depression, and anxiety compared to routine nursing alone, with statistically significant results. The study concluded that laughter therapy is effective for these psychological symptoms in cancer patients.
population_specificity: Cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of laughter yoga on hope and school burnout among eighth-grade students.
results_summary: Laughter yoga significantly reduced school burnout scores and increased hope scores in the intervention group compared to the control group, with statistically significant differences (p < .05).
population_specificity: 60 eighth-grade middle school students (30 intervention, 30 control).
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 35-40 minutes per session, totaling six sessions.
study_duration: Six sessions (exact total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of laughter yoga (LY) on nursing students' well-being, perceived stress, and academic self-efficacy.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant increase in well-being and a decrease in perceived stress after LY, but no statistically significant differences were found between the intervention and control groups for well-being, perceived stress, or academic self-efficacy.
population_specificity: Nursing students (n=83, intervention group n=41, control group n=42)
study_duration: Not specified (only the number of sessions is mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of laughter therapy on perceived stress levels and quality of life in women with breast cancer receiving chemotherapy.
results_summary: Laughter therapy significantly reduced perceived stress and improved both physical and mental quality-of-life scores in women with breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy compared to the control group. The differences between groups were statistically significant (P < .001).
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer receiving chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 40 minutes of laughter therapy twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of laughter therapy on self-efficacy and psychological well-being in nursing students.
results_summary: Laughter therapy increased psychological well-being scores in the experimental group, reduced stress and anxiety, improved eating and sleeping habits, and decreased social media use. However, no statistically significant differences were found in pre- and post-comparisons for all scale scores.
population_specificity: Nursing students (208 participants, randomized into experimental and control groups).
effective_dosage: Face-to-face laughter therapy once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of online laughter yoga on sleep quality and vasomotor symptoms in menopausal women.
results_summary: The laughter yoga group showed significantly reduced vasomotor symptoms and improved sleep quality compared to the control group, with statistically significant differences in posttest scores.
population_specificity: Menopausal women attending the Menopause School (n=36).
effective_dosage: Eight online laughter yoga sessions, two sessions per week.

study_goal: To assess whether laughter exercise is non-inferior to artificial tears in relieving symptoms of dry eye disease.
results_summary: Laughter exercise was non-inferior to artificial tears in improving ocular surface discomfort and showed better improvement in tear film stability. No adverse events were reported in either group.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-45 with symptomatic dry eye disease and specific ocular surface disease index scores.
effective_dosage: Vocalizing specific phrases 30 times per 5-minute session, four times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of laughter yoga on perceived stress, job motivation, and mental well-being in intensive care nurses.
results_summary: Laughter yoga did not significantly change perceived stress levels or work motivation in nurses, but it showed a statistically significant (though clinically modest) improvement in mental well-being scores for the intervention group.
population_specificity: Nurses working in surgical and anesthesia intensive care units at a university hospital in Turkey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of laughter yoga and music intervention on depression, anxiety, and stress in elderly individuals.
results_summary: Both laughter yoga and music interventions significantly reduced depressive and anxiety symptoms, with laughter yoga showing superior effects and better acceptance. Stress reduction was most notable immediately post-intervention but showed some increase at follow-up.
population_specificity: Aged individuals (60-75 years) referred to Rafsanjan health centers with depression.
effective_dosage: Laughter yoga sessions twice a week for eight weeks (specific duration per session not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate laughter-induced seizures, an extremely rare form of reflex epilepsy, and explore potential treatment strategies.
results_summary: The study documented a case of laughter-induced seizures in a patient with no prior medical history, finding that lifestyle modifications helped manage seizures despite normal EEG and neuroimaging results. It highlighted the lack of data on this condition and called for further research into its pathophysiology and treatment.
population_specificity: A single patient with no prior medical or neuropsychiatric history experiencing laughter-induced seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Laughter Yoga on hemodialysis patients' quality of life and other health outcomes.
results_summary: Laughter Yoga showed improvements in life quality, pain severity, sleep quality, subjective well-being, mood, depression, blood pressure, and vital capacity in hemodialysis patients, though the overall effect was deemed inconclusive.
population_specificity: End-stage renal disease patients receiving hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of laughter yoga on the quality of life of cancer patients, focusing on evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
results_summary: Laughter yoga significantly improved the quality of life of cancer patients by enhancing emotional and physical functioning and reducing symptoms of depression and stress. The findings suggest it is a promising complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) practice for psychological and physical health in cancer patients.
population_specificity: Cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether laughter yoga could reduce test anxiety and educational stress in 8th-grade students.
results_summary: The study found that laughter yoga significantly decreased test anxiety and educational stress scores in the intervention group compared to the control group, with statistically significant effect sizes.
population_specificity: 8th-grade students in Turkey (64 participants, split into intervention and control groups).
effective_dosage: Laughter yoga sessions twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of laughter yoga on happiness and stress levels in nursing students entering clinical practice for the first time.
results_summary: Laughter yoga significantly increased happiness scores (p < 0.05) and reduced stress scores in the intervention group (p = 0.001), though no significant difference in stress was found between groups post-intervention (p = 0.081).
population_specificity: Nursing students in Turkey attending clinical practice for the first time.
effective_dosage: Eight laughter yoga lessons over 4 weeks.
